ygData.subject: Re: Roving Eye Paper
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Derek, I m glad you found the paper interesting. ... It always started in the center, facing in the same direction. ... Probably it wouldn t react that well

Hi Derek, I'm glad you found the paper interesting. 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> --- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> > Here is a link to our new
> > paper on evolving
> > a roving eye for Go:
> > 
> > http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04
> 
> I just finished reading the paper, Ken.  Interesting
> stuff.  The basic approach to the "roving eye" makes
> sense...so does the way you implemented it.
> 
> I have a couple of questions, though.
> 
> What was the initial position of the eye at the
> beginning of its turn?  Did it begin where it was
> positioned at the end of the last turn, or does it
> always start from a set position (e.g., the center)?
> 

It always started in the center, facing in the same direction.

> I notice that both the 5x5 and 7x7 roving eye players
> form a vertical border down the center of the board as
> effective strategies.  How would they react if the
> play from GnuGo was transformed rotationally?
> 

Probably it wouldn't react that well since it wasn't trained for that,
but I'm not sure since on the other hand it can in principle handle
rotational symmetry just by turning.

> Is it possible the eye players are just memorizing a
> sequence of moves against GnuGo?  GnuGo plays
> deterministically, right?  Is the roving eye robust
> enough to adapt if GnuGo plays slightly different from
> game to game (e.g., rotating the board, slightly
> randomizing its play)?
> 

It's basically only able to play against the deterministic strategy of
Gnugo.  You could call this memorization, though I think that's
misleading since it implies a sequence is being memorized.  Rather,
what it really is doing is a kind of object recognition.  In other
words, it knows how to look at a board, and using its memory hold
enough
information to determine what state the board is in, and then place
the piece in the right position.  Such a methodology is not entirely
brittle, since it is somewhat heuristic.  In other words, it knows
things like if two black pieces are lined up next to each other, a
third should be placed in the same line (note I said things like this,
not necessarily this particular fact).  This pseudo-generality can be
seen in
 figure 3, when the eye plays on a 7x7 board having never seen such a
board.  In that case, Gnugo's play is quite different from what it's
seen before, yet it still manages to create a semi-contiguous line. 
Thus, it is not purely memorizing a single move sequence.

Another point about what is *is* memorizing if anything: it is
memorizing the board states and the corresponding correct moves.  The
board states however can only be represented through recurrency.  But
the thing is, there is no way it has literally recorded all 30 or so
board states in a single game in its genome.  Rather, it has encoded a
set of heuristics which map to correct play in the states encountered
against Gnugo, so of course these heuristics are more general than
specific positions, and therefore can apply to games it hasn't seen.

That said, without doubt, this methodology is totally biased towards
playing Gnugo and only Gnugo.  But it is a proof concept, that a
rather sophisticated set of heuristics learned on a 5x5 board can be
used and maintained when moving up to 7x7.  It is not meant (as you
understand) to imply this is how to get a general player.

> I've found, just experimenting with Tic-Tac-Toe, that
> ANNs evolved against deterministic players are very
> brittle.  Ones evolved against semi-random players
> tend to be more robust in general.  
> 

Yes absolutely as I said it's not about general play.

> The roving eye networks were composed of 30 inputs and
> 5 outputs.  That means an initial minimal toplogy of
> 185 genes, correct?  (35 nodes + 150 connections.) 

Actually if you look at section 4.3, a bunch of sensors started out
disconnected, and were connected in only through evolution when it was
useful.  I think 8 of the inputs (so 16 sensors) started out
disconnected, but the text gives the specifics.  So the initial
topology was more like 70 connections.

> You used a fairly low node mutation rate (0.0045) and
> an add-connection mutation rate of (0.1).  What were
> the sizes of some of your champion networks?  
> 

As I mentioned in my message to Darren, I uploaded a picture of a
winning network that can be seen
in the photos section.  It has 65 nodes and 368 connection genes (a
few of which were disabled).  Other solutions were the same order of
magnitude.

ken
